Wiley：拉曼光谱杂志：目录https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10974555?af=R拉曼光谱杂志目录。最新期和 EarlyView 期的文章列表。 en-US © 约翰·威利父子有限公司wileyonlinelibrary@wiley.com（分析科学期刊） Mon, 16 Oct 2023 07:04:35 +0000 2023 年 10 月 16 日星期一 07:04:35 +0000 Atypon®文学™ https://validator.w3.org/feed/docs/rss2.html 10080 Wiley：拉曼光谱杂志：目录威利拉曼光谱杂志 Wiley：拉曼光谱杂志：目录https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/pb-assets/journal-banners/10974555.jpg https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10974555?af=R https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6610?af=R Thu, 12 Oct 2023 01:34:04 -0700 2023-10-12T01:34:04-07:00 Wiley：拉曼光谱杂志：目录 10.1002/jrs.6610通过共焦拉曼光谱体内评估神经酰胺纳米乳液的皮肤渗透性和功效拉曼光谱学杂志，EarlyView。通过基于 Cer-NP 拉曼信号的拉曼共焦光谱 (CRM)，从定性和半定量的角度研究了神经酰胺 NP 纳米乳液 (Cer-NP NE) 在皮肤中的渗透性。此外，根据皮肤中脂质和水分子拉曼信号的变化，表明使用Cer-NP NEs处理的皮肤比使用游离Cer-NP NEs处理的皮肤具有更高的含水量和更强的屏障功能。 。摘要 神经酰胺纳米粒子（Cer-NP）对于治疗皮肤干燥和屏障损伤具有良好的效果。然而，它们的功效受到相对较低的皮肤渗透性的阻碍。化妆品领域评价药物渗透性最常用的方法是弗朗兹扩散池，该方法在实验材料和操作方面存在局限性，难以可靠地量化药物在人体皮肤上的体内渗透性。相比之下，共焦拉曼光谱 (CRM) 被认为是一种追踪活性分子穿过皮肤渗透的多功能工具，它是非侵入性、非破坏性和实时的，可以在体内测试神经酰胺的渗透性和渗透性。功效也。本研究的目的是追踪 Cer-NP 纳米乳液（NE）对前臂内侧皮肤的渗透，并评估 Cer-NP 对角质层（SC）厚度、水合作用和细胞间脂质的短期影响(ICL) 构象顺序使用水含量和侧向堆积顺序 Slat = I2880/I2850，这是通过 CRM 数据获得的。 Cer-NP渗透到SC和表皮中，渗透量随着深度的增加而减少，随着时间的延长而增加，最终保留在SC中。结果还发现 Cer-NP 促进 SC 水合作用并增加 SC 厚度和板层。上述研究表明Cer-NP NEs成功渗透皮肤并发挥保湿和屏障修复功能。 ;

;通过拉曼共焦光谱 (CRM) 从定性和半定量的角度研究了神经酰胺纳米乳液 (Cer-NP NE) 在皮肤中的渗透性Cer-NP 的拉曼信号。此外，根据皮肤中脂质和水分子拉曼信号的变化，证明使用Cer-NP NEs处理的皮肤比使用游离Cer-NP处理的皮肤具有更高的含水量和更强的屏障功能。

;
;

;摘要

;

;神经酰胺纳米粒子（Cer-NP）对于治疗皮肤干燥和屏障损伤有良好的效果；然而，它们的功效受到相对较低的皮肤渗透性的阻碍。化妆品领域评价药物渗透性最常用的方法是弗朗兹扩散池，该方法在实验材料和操作方面存在局限性，难以可靠地量化药物在人体皮肤上的体内渗透性。相比之下，共焦拉曼光谱 (CRM) 被认为是跟踪活性分子穿过皮肤渗透的多功能工具，它是非侵入性、非破坏性和实时的，可以在体内测试神经酰胺的渗透性和渗透性。功效也。本研究的目的是追踪 Cer-NP 纳米乳液（NE）对前臂内侧皮肤的渗透，并评估 Cer-NP 对角质层（SC）厚度、水合作用和细胞间脂质的短期影响(ICL) 构象顺序，使用通过 CRM 数据获得的含水量和横向堆积顺序 S;lat; = I;2880;/I;2850;。 Cer-NP渗透到SC和表皮中，渗透量随着深度的增加而减少，随着时间的延长而增加，最终保留在SC中。结果还发现 Cer-NP 促进 SC 水合作用并增加 SC 厚度和 S;lat;。上述研究表明，Cer-NP NEs成功渗透皮肤，发挥保湿和屏障修复功能。

;徐凡、朱军、张泽、李书静、何一凡、董银茂、詹鑫研究文章通过共焦拉曼光谱体内评估神经酰胺纳米乳液的皮肤渗透性和功效10.1002/jrs.6610拉曼光谱杂志10.1002/jrs.6610 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6610?af=R 研究文章 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6607?af=R Wed, 11 Oct 2023 03:04:13 -0700 2023-10-11T03:04:13-07:00 Wiley：拉曼光谱杂志：目录 10.1002/jrs.6607 AgFeO2 颗粒修饰的 MoS2 片材的应变和电荷掺杂效应拉曼光谱学杂志，EarlyView。制备了 AgFeO2 装饰的 MoS2 (M:A) 片。使用拉曼光谱研究 M:A 样品中局部应变和电荷掺杂的演变。 MoS2 的拉曼模式表明，M:A 样品中 MoS2 是 n 掺杂的，并且受到拉伸应变。摘要 二维 (2D) 材料中局部应变的存在会极大地改变其性能。当二维材料的表面被其他纳米材料装饰时，表面会产生局部应变，从而产生协同效应。目前的研究重点是解释在二维材料中观察到的这种局部应变诱导现象。在这项工作中，我们利用拉曼光谱研究了铁氧体银 (AgFeO2) 颗粒装饰的 MoS2 中局部应变和电荷掺杂的演变。 MoS2:AgFeO2 (M:A) 样品是通过在 MoS2 片中添加不同量的 AgFeO2 颗粒来制备的。 M:A 样品的局部应变和电荷掺杂是根据观察到的 MoS2 拉曼活性模式的变化估计的，即 E2g1$$ {E}_{2g}^1 $$ (∼3​​83.1 cm−1) 和A1g$$ {A}_{1g} $$ (∼408.1 cm−1)。 M:A 样品与裸 MoS2 相比，E2g1$$ {E}_{2g}^1 $$ 和 A1g$$ {A}_{1g} $$ 模式的强度也表现出放大的增强。这些发现为设计 MoS2 的表面特性提供了一条新途径。 ;

;这里开创性地将 0 K 下的密度泛函理论计算和原位温度实验结合起来，揭示了单斜硅藻土复杂的拉曼光谱 (PbSiO<子>;3;）。我们报告了选定模式的振动分配、温度波数系数和等压模式 Grüneisen 参数，涵盖 10 至 1000 K 温度范围内的低波数和高波数光谱区域。

;
; < h2>;摘要;

;将密度泛函理论计算与单斜铝硅石（PbSiO;3;）的拉曼振动模式、温度波数系数和等压模式 Grüneisen 参数相结合，开创性地表征了;原位;非偏振拉曼测量。没有观察到结构相变，证实了单斜晶相在 1000 K 之前的热稳定性。

; RB 佩纳、TR 库尼亚、EO 戈麦斯、DV 桑帕约、AD 罗德里格斯、J. 安德烈斯、PS 皮萨尼研究文章铝铜矿（PbSiO3）的振动拉曼模式：结合密度泛函理论计算和原位温度实验10.1002/jrs.6605拉曼光谱杂志10.1002/jrs.6605 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6605?af=R 研究文章 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6602?af=R Thu, 05 Oct 2023 02:54:14 -0700 2023-10-05T02:54:14-07:00 Wiley：拉曼光谱杂志：目录 10.1002/jrs.6602拉曼光谱作为监测绝经后骨质疏松症治疗骨质疏松症的工具拉曼光谱学杂志，EarlyView。骨活性药物系统地影响人类的角蛋白结构。基于人类指甲拉曼光谱的模型可以区分经过治疗和未经治疗的个体。模型与先前的骨质疏松症模型相关。随着时间的推移，未经治疗的个体表现出骨质疏松风险增加的趋势，而接受治疗的个体则表现出逆转，表明风险降低。摘要 基于双膦酸盐的骨质疏松症药物治疗可降低骨折风险，但骨矿物质密度的调节并不能单独解释这一点。需要更好地了解影响脆性的其他骨质量方面以及监测它们的方法。影响骨胶原重塑的全身因素也会同时重塑角蛋白。在这项研究中，对接受和不接受骨活性药物干预的受试者的人类指甲剪进行了比较。判别模型能够区分指甲与未接受过治疗以及测试集中曲线下面积为 71% 的患者的指甲。相对于基线的时间序列变化显示，1 年后，治疗组的分数（95 置信区间 37% 至 377% 变化）与 12 周测量值（−198% 至 34%）和未治疗组的分数不同受试者（−92％至−674％）。对光谱差异和模型系数的分析揭示了与之前三个骨质疏松症模型中观察到的相反的特征，表明治疗正在恢复受损的蛋白质结构。这项研究提供了初步证据，表明骨活性药物系统地影响人类角蛋白结构，并对其潜在机制进行了一些讨论。该研究表明双膦酸盐对蛋白质结构有直接影响，值得进一步研究这些影响。 ;

;纯 P3HT 薄膜的振动热激子态激发后的极化子对动力学和仅 P3HT 二极管已被研究。我们证明了 p 偏振激发光的入射角以及二极管器件的内部和外部电场都会影响动力学。系统地研究了场致解离以及光和电场致极化效应。

;
;

;摘要

;

;我们研究了有机半导体光电器件中振动热激子态激发后的极化子对动力学，以更好地了解其光物理性质，可以帮助提高设备性能。在我们早期的工作中，发表在 ';Phys.化学。化学。 Phys;., 2019,21, 21236-21248'，我们研究了纯聚（3-己基噻吩-2,5-二基）中静电内部和外部场对极化子对动力学的作用基于设备。由此，我们得出结论，由于器件内部存在内部场，极化子对解离成电荷载流子，并且当在反向偏压下也施加外部电场时，解离过程会加速。除了电场诱导的解离过程之外，我们现在还对光和电场诱导的极化效应对极化子对动力学的影响感兴趣。为此，在本研究中，我们使用飞秒瞬态吸收光谱来研究基于 P3HT 的纯器件中不同光入射角以及静电场附加变化的极化子对动力学。众所周知，薄膜光伏器件可以设计用于改善特定角度下的角度相关响应度，并且光子收集效率取决于光的入射角。内部电场和入射光电场都会影响器件的电荷生成效率，这是由电子激发和电荷形成之间发生的光物理过程决定的。我们的研究表明，入射角变化引起的反射率变化以及电场诱发极化的影响对极化子对动力学产生整体影响。

;德布库玛·拉纳、阿努尔夫·马特尼研究文章洞察纯 P3HT 器件中极化子对动力学的光和静电场诱导偏振：一项基于瞬态吸收光谱的研究10.1002/jrs.6604拉曼光谱杂志10.1002/jrs.6604 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6604?af=R 研究文章 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6579?af=R Fri, 29 Sep 2023 01:18:37 -0700 2023-09-29T01:18:37-07:00 Wiley：拉曼光谱杂志：目录2023 年 9 月 1 日星期五 00:00:00 -0700 2023 年 9 月 1 日星期五 00:00:00 -0700 10.1002/jrs.6579使用宽带光纤激光源对相干拉曼散射光谱中的光谱覆盖范围和光谱分辨率进行数值评估《拉曼光谱杂志》，第 54 卷，第 9 期，第 1001-1010 页，2023 年 9 月。使用数值模拟工具使我们能够评估 CRS 光谱的光谱分辨率和光谱覆盖范围。本文介绍了使用全光纤激光源在 C-H 窗口和指纹区域进行高分辨率 CRS 光谱的初步结果。该仿真工具可以容纳任意形状的光脉冲，是一种用户友好且多功能的开源软件。摘要：我们从理论上研究了使用光纤激光源进行高分辨率和宽带相干拉曼散射（CRS）光谱/成像（采用光谱聚焦技术）的可行性。为了完成这项任务，我们开发了一种模拟工具，可以使用分步傅里叶方法直接从任何脉冲传播软件导入激光脉冲参数，以评估 CRS 光谱的光谱分辨率和光谱覆盖范围。因此，该仿真工具可以容纳任意形状和中心波长的光脉冲，也是一个用户友好且多功能的开源软件。我们通过将其结果与已发表的理论和实验数据进行比较来验证数值模拟工具。然后，我们使用该工具研究使用全光纤激光源在 C-H 窗口和指纹区域进行高分辨率 CRS 光谱的可行性。该工具在 CRS 光谱学有用的多个领域具有广泛的应用，例如生物医学、材料表征和生物成像。 ;

;We report on the positive role of isothiocyanate (ITC) and the negative role of sulfonate (SO) groups in five cyanine dyes on sensitivity and performance of nanotags in NIR-SERRS-LFA using our home-built reader with line-focused illumination.

;
;

;Abstract

;

;Surface-enhanced resonance Raman scattering (SERRS) is based on nanostructures supporting localized surface plasmon resonances as well as electronic resonances of the molecular adsorbate. Bright NIR-SERRS nanotags require dyes with high Raman scattering cross-sections upon NIR laser excitation in combination with functional groups for chemisorption. Here, we report on the role of isothiocyanate (ITC) and sulfonate (SO) groups in five cyanine dyes on sensitivity and performance of nanotags in SERRS-based LFA. Dye concentration-dependent SERRS and zeta potential measurements on bare gold nanostars (AuNS) revealed strong differences in their sensitivity and stability as a function of the number of ITC and SO groups. A positive correlation with the number of ITC groups due to stronger chemisorption and a negative correlation with the number of SO groups due to stronger desorption because of higher water solubility was observed. The application in SERRS-based biosensing requires additional functionalization steps, for example, co-adsorption of PEG with the NIR dye. The comparison of the Raman intensities before and after bioconjugation showed that the presence of at least one ITC group is necessary for minimizing Raman signal losses, irrespective of the additional presence of SO groups. In a SERRS-based lateral flow assay (LFA) for sensing the pregnancy marker beta-hCG, the two dyes NIR 4f and NIR 5e (both ITC = 2, SO = 0) showed the best performance. In contrast, we do not recommend to use IR-783 (ITC = 0, SO = 2) for SERRS-based biosensing. Overall, this study highlights the importance of surface-seeking moieties such as the common ITC group for optimal performance in SERRS-based biosensing platforms.

; Namhyun Choi, Mujo Adanalic, Asen Dankov, Roland Grzeschik, Michelle Hechler, Sebastian Schlücker SPECIAL ISSUE ‐ RESEARCH ARTICLE NIR dye‐encoded nanotags for biosensing: Role of functional groups on sensitivity and performance in SERRS‐based LFA 10.1002/jrs.6519 Journal of Raman Spectroscopy 10.1002/jrs.6519 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6519?af=R SPECIAL ISSUE ‐ RESEARCH ARTICLE 54 9 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6528?af=R Fri, 29 Sep 2023 01:18:37 -0700 2023-09-29T01:18:37-07:00 Wiley: Journal of Raman Spectroscopy: Table of Contents Fri, 01 Sep 2023 00:00:00 -0700 Fri, 01 Sep 2023 00:00:00 -0700 10.1002/jrs.6528 Raman spectroscopy enables non‐invasive and quantitative assessment of macronutrients in baked foods Journal of Raman Spectroscopy, Volume 54, Issue 9, Page 899-904, September 2023. Raman spectroscopy, a non‐invasive, non‐destructive, and label‐free technique, can be used for the quantitative assessment of carbohydrates, gluten, carotenoids, and fats in baked foods, including bread and crackers. This information can be used to balance the diet of millions of people around the world and prevent the development of chronic diseases such as obesity and diabetes. Abstract Fast and accurate assessments of macro and micronutrients in food can be used to balance the diet of millions of people around the world. This can help to prevent the development of chronic diseases such as obesity and diabetes. Modern analytical methods that can be used to reveal information about the nutritional composition of food are destructive and laborious. In this study, we examine the potential of Raman spectroscopy in the non‐invasive, non‐destructive, and quantitative assessment of carbohydrates, gluten, carotenoids, and fats in baked foods, including bread and crackers. The Raman effect is based on the phenomenon of inelastic light scattering. Our results demonstrate that Raman spectroscopy could be used to quantify the amount of carbohydrates, gluten, carotenoids, and fats in baked foods. Furthermore, unique spectroscopic signatures of bread and crackers could be used for their automated identification. These findings demonstrate that Raman‐based sensors can be used to personalize nutrition and control the quality of consumed food products. ;

;Raman spectroscopy, a non-invasive, non-destructive, and label-free technique, can be used for the quantitative assessment of carbohydrates, gluten, carotenoids, and fats in baked foods, including bread and crackers. This information can be used to balance the diet of millions of people around the world and prevent the development of chronic diseases such as obesity and diabetes.

;
;

;Abstract

;

;Fast and accurate assessments of macro and micronutrients in food can be used to balance the diet of millions of people around the world. This can help to prevent the development of chronic diseases such as obesity and diabetes. Modern analytical methods that can be used to reveal information about the nutritional composition of food are destructive and laborious. In this study, we examine the potential of Raman spectroscopy in the non-invasive, non-destructive, and quantitative assessment of carbohydrates, gluten, carotenoids, and fats in baked foods, including bread and crackers. The Raman effect is based on the phenomenon of inelastic light scattering. Our results demonstrate that Raman spectroscopy could be used to quantify the amount of carbohydrates, gluten, carotenoids, and fats in baked foods. Furthermore, unique spectroscopic signatures of bread and crackers could be used for their automated identification. These findings demonstrate that Raman-based sensors can be used to personalize nutrition and control the quality of consumed food products.

; Axell Rodriguez, Dmitry Kurouski SPECIAL ISSUE ‐ RESEARCH ARTICLE Raman spectroscopy enables non‐invasive and quantitative assessment of macronutrients in baked foods 10.1002/jrs.6528 Journal of Raman Spectroscopy 10.1002/jrs.6528 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6528?af=R SPECIAL ISSUE ‐ RESEARCH ARTICLE 54 9 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6539?af=R Fri, 29 Sep 2023 01:18:37 -0700 2023-09-29T01:18:37-07:00 Wiley: Journal of Raman Spectroscopy: Table of Contents Fri, 01 Sep 2023 00:00:00 -0700 Fri, 01 Sep 2023 00:00:00 -0700 10.1002/jrs.6539 Rational design enabling aptamer‐based sensors for surface‐enhanced Raman detection of small molecules Journal of Raman Spectroscopy, Volume 54, Issue 9, Page 966-975, September 2023. A protocol is presented for design of homogeneous SERS sensors for small molecule detection based on the duplex aptamer mechanism. Using the well‐defined ATP aptamer as a model system, the effects of hybridization, ACE, and stabilizer length were explored. Abstract Homogeneous surface‐enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) sensors could have a significant impact in environmental analysis. The reagentless mechanism of these sensors makes them capable for in situ analysis and continuous monitoring of environmental pollutants, without having to collect environmental samples for laboratory analysis. Homogeneous SERS sensors take advantage of functional DNA strands on the surface of a SERS‐active particle. These sensors are commonly used for the detection of genomic targets. A clear path to adapt these homogeneous sensors to detect small molecules is to employ aptamer sequences. In particular, the use of duplex aptamer can make these sensors highly adaptable to different target molecules. Although there have been examples of SERS duplex aptamer sensors to detect small molecules, the design rules for this type of sensors have not been elucidated. Without design rules or a design protocol, we would not be able to fully take advantage of the adaptability of this approach to focus on new targets and applications (eg, environmental analysis). Herein, we aim to define a protocol for the design of aptamer‐based homogeneous SERS sensors. First, we demonstrate their nonequilibrium character and the necessary length for the complementary element for the sensors to work. We demonstrate the design protocol on a well‐characterized aptamer sequence for ATP binding and then transfer the knowledge gained on an aptamer for estradiol, a common water contaminant. In this work, we establish the design protocol for a short aptamer (ie, ATP) and analyze the issues and remedies associated with extending this protocol to longer aptamer sequences (eg, E2). ;

;A protocol is presented for design of homogeneous SERS sensors for small molecule detection based on the duplex aptamer mechanism. Using the well-defined ATP aptamer as a model system, the effects of hybridization, ACE, and stabilizer length were explored.

;
;

;Abstract

;

;Homogeneous surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) sensors could have a significant impact in environmental analysis. The reagentless mechanism of these sensors makes them capable for in situ analysis and continuous monitoring of environmental pollutants, without having to collect environmental samples for laboratory analysis. Homogeneous SERS sensors take advantage of functional DNA strands on the surface of a SERS-active particle. These sensors are commonly used for the detection of genomic targets. A clear path to adapt these homogeneous sensors to detect small molecules is to employ aptamer sequences. In particular, the use of duplex aptamer can make these sensors highly adaptable to different target molecules. Although there have been examples of SERS duplex aptamer sensors to detect small molecules, the design rules for this type of sensors have not been elucidated. Without design rules or a design protocol, we would not be able to fully take advantage of the adaptability of this approach to focus on new targets and applications (eg, environmental analysis). Herein, we aim to define a protocol for the design of aptamer-based homogeneous SERS sensors. First, we demonstrate their nonequilibrium character and the necessary length for the complementary element for the sensors to work. We demonstrate the design protocol on a well-characterized aptamer sequence for ATP binding and then transfer the knowledge gained on an aptamer for estradiol, a common water contaminant. In this work, we establish the design protocol for a short aptamer (ie, ATP) and analyze the issues and remedies associated with extending this protocol to longer aptamer sequences (eg, E2).

; Lyndsay N. Kissell, Manisha Sheokand, Pietro Strobbia SPECIAL ISSUE ‐ RESEARCH ARTICLE Rational design enabling aptamer‐based sensors for surface‐enhanced Raman detection of small molecules 10.1002/jrs.6539 Journal of Raman Spectroscopy 10.1002/jrs.6539 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6539?af=R SPECIAL ISSUE ‐ RESEARCH ARTICLE 54 9 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6562?af=R Fri, 29 Sep 2023 01:18:37 -0700 2023-09-29T01:18:37-07:00 Wiley: Journal of Raman Spectroscopy: Table of Contents Fri, 01 Sep 2023 00:00:00 -0700 Fri, 01 Sep 2023 00:00:00 -0700 10.1002/jrs.6562 Surface‐enhanced Raman imaging of intact cancer cell membrane on a rough aluminum substrate Journal of Raman Spectroscopy, Volume 54, Issue 9, Page 940-949, September 2023. We performed SERS imaging of intact cell membranes on rough aluminum substrates by comparing them with Si substrates. The comparison of cancer and normal cell membranes revealed different lipid/protein peak ratios in cytoplasm and nucleus‐proximal areas. Abstract The plasma membrane of cancer cells displays differences in lipid and protein composition which distinguish them from healthy cells. Certain molecules have such prominent vibrational characteristics that they can be considered cancer biomarkers. Although Raman spectroscopy is a label‐free non‐invasive method of chemical analysis, it, however, has been limited by weak signals from the membrane compared to the bulk interior of cells. Surface‐enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) on plasmonic gold and silver substrates has previously been used to overcome this limitation. However, the high cost, poor repeatability, and toxicity of these noble metals hinder their practical applications. These challenges may be solved by using different materials and nanostructures. Here, we performed SERS imaging of ovarian cancer cells on rough aluminum substrates and extracted the Raman signals of intact cell membranes by comparing these with the corresponding measurements on Si substrates. We used atomic force microscopy (AFM) for Raman signal calibration. The comparison of cancer and normal cell membranes revealed the different lipid/protein peak ratios in cytoplasm and nucleus‐proximal areas. These Raman signatures of the ovarian cancer can be used as new biomarkers. This method may be extended to other types of cancer biosensing based on aluminum plasmonics. ;

;We performed SERS imaging of intact cell membranes on rough aluminum substrates by comparing them with Si substrates. The comparison of cancer and normal cell membranes revealed different lipid/protein peak ratios in cytoplasm and nucleus-proximal areas.

;
;

;Abstract

;

;The plasma membrane of cancer cells displays differences in lipid and protein composition which distinguish them from healthy cells. Certain molecules have such prominent vibrational characteristics that they can be considered cancer biomarkers. Although Raman spectroscopy is a label-free non-invasive method of chemical analysis, it, however, has been limited by weak signals from the membrane compared to the bulk interior of cells. Surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) on plasmonic gold and silver substrates has previously been used to overcome this limitation. However, the high cost, poor repeatability, and toxicity of these noble metals hinder their practical applications. These challenges may be solved by using different materials and nanostructures. Here, we performed SERS imaging of ovarian cancer cells on rough aluminum substrates and extracted the Raman signals of intact cell membranes by comparing these with the corresponding measurements on Si substrates. We used atomic force microscopy (AFM) for Raman signal calibration. The comparison of cancer and normal cell membranes revealed the different lipid/protein peak ratios in cytoplasm and nucleus-proximal areas. These Raman signatures of the ovarian cancer can be used as new biomarkers. This method may be extended to other types of cancer biosensing based on aluminum plasmonics.
